questions.text: Which of the following arteries is most commonly involved in patients with coronary artery disease?
questions.solution:
The left anterior descending (anterior interventricular) coronary artery is most commonly involved in coronary artery disease (CAD) or coronary heart disease or ischemic heart disease.

The regions affected are the anterior wall of the left ventricle near the apex and the anterior portion of the ventricular septum.

CAD is caused by plaque buildup in the walls of the coronary arteries that narrow over time and can partially or totally block the blood flow causing myocardial ischemia and subsequently infarction. 

The image below shows coronary circulation.

questions.text: Which area of the myocardium is most vulnerable to damage in patients with ischemic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Subendocardium is the region of the myocardium most vulnerable to ischemic damage.

The myocardium is perfused from the epicardium to the endocardium. This results in the subendocardium being the least perfused region making it most vulnerable to ischemic damage.

A narrow zone of the myocardium immediately beneath the endocardium is spared from necrosis because it can be oxygenated by diffusion from the ventricle.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. 

ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.

These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome. 

Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected stable angina, which of the following findings are likely to be present?

choices.text: CK-MB is elevated ; Troponin T is normal
Troponin I is elevated ; Myoglobin is normal
Myoglobin is elevated ; CK-MB is normal
Troponin I is normal ; CK-MB is normal

questions.solution:
The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no necrosis of cardiac myocytes.

The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into: 

  • Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes
    • Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates  
  • Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes
    • Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no elevation of biomarkers
    • Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition

questions.text: While evaluating a patient with chest pain in the emergency, you ask him to localize the sensation. He places a hand over the sternum with a clenched fist. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
When a patient with angina is asked to localize the sensation, he or she typically places a hand over the sternum, sometimes with a clenched fist, to indicate a squeezing, central, substernal discomfort. This is called Levine’s sign.

Option A: Mayne's sign- Drop of at least 15 mmHg in the diastolic blood pressure on raising the arm. It occurs in patients with aortic regurgitation (not reliable).

Option C: Frank’s sign- Diagonal crease in the ear lobe indicative of cardiovascular diseases and/or diabetes.

Option D: Friedreich's sign- Exaggerated drop in JVP seen in constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with chest discomfort, associated with a squeezing sensation in the substernal area. She added that it was precipitated by physical activity and relieved on taking rest. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina in which the pain is usually crescendo-decrescendo in nature.

Characteristic features of pain in stable angina:

  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature
  • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
  • Can radiate occasionally to neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, left arm.

Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles, that radiation pattern is more typical of pericarditis.

Features Stable angina Unstable angina
Pain
  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort.
  • Crescendo-decrescendo pattern.
  • Precipitated by exercise, cold weather, or emotional stress duration of 2-5 min.
  • Same as stable angina but may be more severe.
  • Crescendo pattern.
  • Pain occurs at rest and may last up to 20 min.

 

 
Pathology

Ischemia due to fixed stenosis

Unstable plaques causing dynamic obstruction
Predictability

Predictable

Unpredictable
Diagnosis
  • ECG during exercise
  • ECG during exercise contraindicated
  • Coronary angiography recommended
ECG
  • ECG at rest: normal
  • ECG in exercise: ST-segment depression and ischemic T-waves
  • ECG at rest: ST-segment depression and ischemic T-waves

questions.text: A patient presented with angina and ECG showed ST-segment elevation. The pulse rate was found to be 54 beats/min and blood pressure was 98/56 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of STEMI with bradycardia which is a feature of inferior wall myocardial infarction. Up to one-half with inferior infarction show evidence of parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and/or hypotension).

Many patients have a normal pulse rate and blood pressure within the first hour of STEMI.

About one-fourth of patients with anterior infarction have manifestations of sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and/or hypertension).

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A patient was admitted with acute MI. During a daily examination, a transient murmur was heard. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution: A transient midsystolic or late systolic apical murmur due to mitral regurgitation secondary to dysfunction of the mitral valve apparatus (papillary muscle dysfunction, LV dilation) may be present in STEMI.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers is the earliest to rise after acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by troponin, CK-MB and then LDH.

Serum myoglobin and heart-type fatty acid-binding protein are smaller molecules that diffuse through interstitial ﬂuids more rapidly after cell death than the larger CK and troponin molecules. They become abnormal as early as 30 minutes after myocardial injury. Neither molecule is specific to myocardial tissue. Myoglobin levels are not tested in routine practice.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: A patient is under evaluation for acute MI. Which of the following biomarkers would you prefer to test for?
questions.solution:
The most preferred cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI amongst the given options is cardiac troponin-I.

Cardiac troponin-I, CK-MB, and myoglobin are significantly more specific for acute-MI than cardiac troponin-T. 

The cardiac troponins are particularly valuable when there is clinical suspicion of a small MI that may be below the detection limit for CK-MB measurement. They have replaced CK-MB as the biomarker of choice for diagnosing myocardial infarction.

Cardiac troponins:

  • Most specific cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI
  • Elevations are useful for short & long-term prognoses in MI
  • Elevations correlate with the estimation of infarct size and risk of death
  • Newer highly sensitive assays for troponins become positive within the first 3 hours after onset of chest pain in MI

questions.text: Elevated cardiac troponins may not be seen in which of the following patients?

choices.text: A 65-year-old woman suffering from Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
A patient who underwent cardioversion for VT in the emergency room

questions.solution:
Troponins are not elevated in patients suffering from angina. Troponins are elevated in the case of myocardial necrosis (seen in MI) whereas angina is associated with myocardial insufficiency/ischemia. 

Conditions associated with an elevation in cardiac troponins:

  • MI
  • Myocarditis
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • Myocardial contusion
  • Cardioversion/defibrillation
  • LV strain from CHF
  • Hypertensive crisis
  • RV strain from PE
  • Renal disease
  • Sepsis

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is preferred for diagnosing reinfarction in a patient post-NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Troponin(serial) is the preferred biomarker for diagnosing reinfarction.

Serial troponin levels are used to detect reinfarction, an acute MI that occurs within 28 days of an incident or recurrent MI. 

In case of suspected reinfarction, an immediate measurement of cardiac troponin followed by a second sample after 3-6 hours. ≥20 percent rise in the second sample suggests reinfarction.


Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: Which of the following is likely to be seen in a patient diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction?

choices.text: Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 2 <  1 in plasma
Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 2 > 1 in plasma
Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 4 < 1 in plasma
Ratio of LDH 2 / LDH 1 > 1 in plasma

questions.solution:
In myocardial injury, the LDH-1 fraction increases, and the ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 becomes >1 in the plasma. This is called flipped LDH pattern.

Normally, the LDH-2 fraction is greater than the LDH-1 fraction in the plasma, and therefore, the ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 is normally <1.

questions.text: What is the maximum predicted heart rate in a 50-year-old gentleman on exercise tolerance test?
questions.solution:
Maximum predicted heart rate on an exercise tolerance test (treadmill test) is given by: HRmax = 220 – Age

So in a 50-year-old male, the maximum predicted heart rate is 220 - 50 = 170 bpm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for performing an exercise tolerance test?

choices.text: AAA with transverse diameter of 5.5 cm

questions.solution:
Treadmill exercise testing (treadmill test) may be safely performed in patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Absolute contraindications to exercise testing:

  • Acute myocardial infarction (within 2 days)
  • High-risk unstable angina
  • Uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia with hemodynamic compromise
  • Active endocarditis
  • Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis
  • Decompensated heart failure
  • Acute pulmonary embolism or pulmonary infarction
  • Acute myocarditis or pericarditis
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension
  • Aortic dissection

Relative Contraindications to exercise testing:

  • Known left main coronary artery stenosis
  • Moderate aortic stenosis with uncertain relation to symptoms
  • Tachyarrhythmias with uncontrolled ventricular rates
  • Acquired complete heart block
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with severe resting gradient
  • Mental impairment with limited ability to cooperate

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be used for a patient undergoing stress echocardiography?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine, an alpha-receptor agonist, cannot be used for a patient undergoing stress echocardiography as it causes vasoconstriction. 

Dobutamine (preferred agent) and vasodilators (dipyridamole, adenosine, regadenoson) are used for pharmacological stress echocardiography. 

Pharmacologic stress testing is used in those who cannot exercise because of pulmonary veno-occlusive disease, musculoskeletal disease, or exertional dyspnea.

Stress echocardiography can be done using either exercise (e.g.: treadmill test or bicycle test) or pharmacologic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following findings during an exercise tolerance test is not associated with multivessel coronary artery disease?

choices.text: Persistence of ST segment changes late into recovery phase
Failure to increase systolic BP by at least 20mmHg

questions.solution:
A failure to increase systolic blood pressure by 10 mm Hg, or a sustained decrease in systolic blood pressure of 10 mm Hg or more, is suggestive of multivessel (or left main) CAD.

Other abnormalities on exercise testing that are suggestive of multivessel CAD include:

  • Early-onset of ischemic ST-segment depression
  • ST-segment depression of ≥2 mm (0.2mV) involving 5 or more leads, or persisting ≥5 minutes into recovery
  • Exercise-induced ST-segment elevation is also consistent with multivessel CAD
  • Recent evidence suggests that ST-segment elevation of ≥1 mm in lead aVR may be a significant predictor of left main coronary artery disease, proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery disease, or at least multivessel CAD

An exercise tolerance/treadmill test involves walking in place on a treadmill while monitoring the electrical activity of your heart. Throughout the test, the speed and incline of the treadmill increase. The results show how well your heart responds to the stress of different levels of exercise.

World Heart Day is observed annually on September 29th. The aim of this campaign is to beat the cardiovascular disease, it is something that matters to every beating heart. This year's theme is USE HEART FOR EVERY HEART.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is used for myocardial perfusion imaging?
questions.solution: Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).

questions.text: A patient is being considered for CABG in order to achieve coronary revascularization. Which of the following test will not be useful to assess myocardial viability for predicting the risk of perioperative morbidity?
questions.solution:
Modalities for the determination of myocardial viability include:

  • Thallium-201 imaging
  • MRI
  • Dobutamine echocardiography
  • PET scan (investigation of choice)

The investigation of choice for assessing the ventricular function is cardiac MRI.

questions.text: Which questionnaire is used for the assessment of a patient who presented with symptoms of angina?
questions.solution:
WHO Rose questionnaire is used for the assessment of angina.

Option B: International prostate symptom score (IPSS) questionnaire is used for BPH.

Option C: The CAGE questionnaire is used to check for signs of possible alcohol dependency.

Option D: The youth tobacco survey (YTS) questionnaire is used to study the prevalence of use of tobacco products amongst youth.

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings is first to appear in a patient suspected of acute myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
During acute myocardial infarction, the ECG evolves through 3 stages:

  1. T-wave peaking and T-wave inversion: 
    • Peaked T-wave aka hyperacute T-wave- first ECG change (occurs within minutes)
    • If the blood flow is restored or the oxygen demands of the heart are met, the T waves will revert to normal
    • If myocardial cell death has occurred, T wave inversions appear (over days) and persist for months to years.
    • A nonspecific finding and is indicative only of ischemia and not diagnostic of infarction
  2. ST-segment elevation occurs over minutes to hours (after T-wave peaking)
  3. The appearance of new pathologic Q-waves:
    • Occurs over hours to days (after ST-segment elevation) and is indicative of an evolving MI
    • The persistence of pathological Q-waves indicates irreversible myocardial cell death

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.solution:
Measurement of troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours.

 

Troponin T/I:

  • Highly specific for MI
  • Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.
  • This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis).
  • Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction.
  • Sometimes cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. In this case, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement

Creatine kinase (CK):

  • Less sensitive and specific than troponins
  • When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • Normally, LDH2>LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1>LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

Myoglobin:

  • Earliest enzyme to increase after MI.
  • Not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.

Heart-type fatty acid-binding protein (H-FABP), which mainly exists in cardiomyocytes, has recently emerged as a potential biomarker, which was found to be sensitive for the early diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction. H-FABP as an early marker and cTnI as a late marker would be the ideal combination to cover the complete diagnostic window for AMI

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with an ST-segment elevation?
questions.solution:
There is no ST-segment elevation in unstable angina.

Differential diagnosis of ST-segment elevation (Mnemonic-ELEVATION):

  • Electrolytes(Hypercalcemia, Hyperkalemia)
  • Left bundle branch block
  • Early(Benign) repolarization, Embolism(Acute pulmonary)
  • Ventricular hypertrophy
  • Arrhythmia(Brugada syndrome), Aneurysm of LV, Aortic dissection, Antiarrhythmic drugs(Class 1c)
  • Tako-tsubo syndrome, Tumor invading left ventricle, Trauma to ventricles
  • Infarction(MI), Inflammation(Myocarditis, Pericarditis)
  • Osborn J waves (Hypothermia or hypercalcemia)
  • Non-atherosclerotic vasospasm(Prinzmetal's angina)
